subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth
msgSnippet: hello Ewout and Brian, Ewout wrote: I am not sure, but I thought there was somebody discussing about a corpus of normal modern texts, so we could find out
messageBody:
hello Ewout and Brian,

 

Ewout wrote:

 

I am not sure, but I thought there was somebody discussing about a
corpus of normal modern texts, so we could find out which sounds
occur the most (either here, on the shavian group or on the
alt.language.artificial newsgroup). the schwa 'a' and the letter n
are probably numbers one and two, but I need to know the ones after
number 26.

 

Actually, Sweet, I think his name is Henry Sweet did a comprehensive study of the most common sounds in the English language. He did this, I believe, in the early 1900s. I had his book at one time, but no longer. I’ll attempt to find a copy and send the most pertinent part of his work to you both. He really did a comprehensive job, for example checking different types literature for whether the most common sounds changed from depending on the type of literature studied. I’m just guessing that there would not be much change between his study results and now. He also studied the most commonly occuring letters and letter combinations in English.

 

I notice that Brian Roberts has posted some results. It would be interesting to compare Sweet’s results to his.

 

Ed

 

 

e-mail: ed.gaddy@...

phone:  301 390 5115

 

-----Original Message-----
From: Teraiten Sovo [mailto:teraiten@...]
Sent: Wednesday, March 06, 2002 9:12 AM
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth

 

--- Ed Gaddy <ed.gaddy@...> wrote: > Hello Ewout,

>
> I enjoyed your comments below. You’ve obviously put some thought
> into this.
> I noticed that you did not mention the possibility of one or two
> keys that
> would make no symbol unless followed by another key. This would
> easily raise
> the number of characters available to that required. Naturally, the
> more
> used characters would take a single stroke, and the less used
> symbols would
> take two strokes.

This I suggested in a few posts ago. I just found out that the actual
driver wasn't attached (no idea why, there was just an empty file),
so I'll try to send it ASAP.

I use the newromaji system as a basis. This uses q, c and x
efficiently, for the sounds 'N', 'c' and 'S'. (sorry, no font support
here)

I am not sure, but I thought there was somebody discussing about a
corpus of normal modern texts, so we could find out which sounds
occur the most (either here, on the shavian group or on the
alt.language.artificial newsgroup). the schwa 'a' and the letter n
are probably numbers one and two, but I need to know the ones after
number 26.

>
> By the by, I’ve used a Dvorak keyboard for about seven years. I
> haven’t
> timed myself. My guess is that I’m just slightly faster than I was
> on a
> “qwerty” keyboard.

On a qwerty I have recently improved my record in typing Dutch. I had
to re-type a line of text on the screen. My previous record was 340
chars/min (in Holland we never measure in words per minute), now it's
365. I first learned how to type when I was twelve. Now I'm
seventeen.
That one hour of training each day has definitely earned itself back.


Ewout

I notice that Brian Roberts has posted some results. It would be interesting

Ed

<tt>This I suggested in a few p=
osts ago. I just found out that the actual</tt><br>
<tt>driver wasn't attac=
hed (no idea why, there was just an empty file),</tt><br>
<tt>so I'll try t=
o send it ASAP.</tt><br>
<br>
<tt>I use the newromaji system as a basis. Th=
is uses q, c and x</tt><br>
<tt>efficiently, for the sounds 'N', 'c' and 'S=
'. (sorry, no font support</tt><br>
<tt>here)</tt><br>
<br>
<tt>I am not su=
re, but I thought there was somebody discussing about a</tt><br>
<tt>corpus=
 of normal modern texts, so we could find out which sounds</tt><br>
<tt>occ=
ur the most (either here, on the shavian group or on the</tt><br>
<tt>alt.l=
anguage.artificial newsgroup). the schwa 'a' and the letter n</tt><br>
<tt>=
are probably numbers one and two, but I need to know the ones after</tt><br=
>
<tt>number 26.</tt><br>
<br>
<tt>> </tt><br>
<tt>> By the by, I&#82=
17;ve used a Dvorak keyboard for about seven years. I</tt><br>
<tt>> hav=
en’t</tt><br>
<tt>> timed myself. My guess is that I’m just =
slightly faster than I was</tt><br>
<tt>> on a</tt><br>
<tt>> “=
qwerty” keyboard.</tt><br>
<br>
<tt>On a qwerty I have recently impro=
ved my record in typing Dutch. I had</tt><br>
<tt>to re-type a line of text=
 on the screen. My previous record was 340</tt><br>
<tt>chars/min (in Holla=
nd we never measure in words per minute), now it's</tt><br>
<tt>365. I firs=
t learned how to type when I was twelve. Now I'm</tt><br>
<tt>seventeen.</t=
t><br>
<tt>That one hour of training each day has definitely earned itself =
back.</tt><br>
<br>
<br>
<tt>Ewout</tt><br>
<br>
<tt>______________________=
